title: Ticket #3792: Claim handling for consumption policies causes crash in startd
description:
Consumption policies (#3435) introduced a memory problem relating to claim data structures maintenance. 

The crash appears to be caused by late references to deleted Claim objects via the r_claims member. this is a typical stack trace for the crash, it doesn't always crash here however.

remarks:
2013-Jul-18 19:36:39 by eje:
I ran a startd with a "legacy" p-slot (one with no consumption policy configured) for about a half hour, under various patterns of job submission, and could not get the startd to crash.

I also ran a few jobs through while running under valgrind, and no memory errors were reported.

I may need a more detailed repro configuration. Logs from the crashing startds might also be useful.

2013-Jul-19 09:26:27 by gthain:
Try running the startd out of resources, so that it gets into the "owner" state.

2013-Jul-19 14:47:06 by eje:
I've definitely run many cycles of depleting all cpus on the startd.

After consulting with Greg, I've also tested:

  • configuring 8 cpus
  • running long jobs (1 hr)
  • reconfiguring the startd while its cpus were depleted

So far, I've failed to repro a startd crash or obtain any memory errors reported from valgrind.

Since upstream currently has experienced the only known repro, I'm requesting that you attempt a repro, and send condor log files, core dumps, and valgrind report. (maybe also complete config file set, just for good measure)

I've been running the startd under valgrind this way: 

VGSTARTD = /usr/bin/valgrind
VGSTARTD_ARGS = --log-file=/tmp/vglog_startd_%p -v --track-origins=yes $(SBIN)/condor_startd -f
DAEMON_LIST = MASTER, COLLECTOR, NEGOTIATOR, SCHEDD, VGSTARTD

2013-Jul-26 20:07:07 by eje:
REPRO/TEST

To reproduce, you need to send a partitionable slot into Owner mode. Either a p-slot with or without a consumption policy will show the behavior. The following config will induce an Owner state when the p-slot runs out of cpus. 

NUM_CPUS = 2

# define a partitionable slot
SLOT_TYPE_1 = 100%
SLOT_TYPE_1_PARTITIONABLE = True
NUM_SLOTS_TYPE_1 = 1

# Crash occurs when slot goes into Owner state.
# Induce p-slot to go into Owner state when it runs out of Cpus.
START = Cpus > 0

# the startd should crash (or not, after fix) regardless of whether
# a consumption policy is enabled:

#CONSUMPTION_POLICY = True
#CONSUMPTION_CPUS = 1
#CONSUMPTION_MEMORY = 10
#CONSUMPTION_DISK = 10
#SLOT_WEIGHT = Cpus
#NEGOTIATOR_USE_SLOT_WEIGHTS = True

# verbose logging
ALL_DEBUG = D_FULLDEBUG

To reproduce, submit a block of jobs (>= number of cpus, in this case, 2). Before fix, it will enter Owner state, and shortly afterward the startd will crash by attempting to access a deallocated claim. After the fix, the crash will not occur.

2013-Jul-27 17:06:51 by eje:
new topic branch including fix for #3792 is: V8_1-gt3792-startd-crashes-fix

Also includes a tweak to accountant logic that enables consumption policies to work smoothly with both accounting groups and concurrency limits, and a new regression test for concurrency limits and accounting groups functionality with consumption policies.

2013-Jul-29 18:22:08 by eje:
Notes on valgrind testing.

I used the following config to invoke the startd under valgrind memory testing: 

VGSTARTD = /usr/bin/valgrind
VGSTARTD_ARGS = --log-file=/tmp/vglog_startd_%p -v --track-origins=yes $(SBIN)/condor_startd -f
DAEMON_LIST = MASTER, COLLECTOR, NEGOTIATOR, SCHEDD, VGSTARTD

I submitted jobs to run a p-slot out of resources and put it into the Owner state. I let the p-slot cycle in and out of Owner state repeatedly for about 30 minutes, while watching StartLog output.

The valgrind output should show zero errors (with the original bug it reported several hundred memory access errors prior to crashing): 

==12585== ERROR SUMMARY: 0 errors from 0 contexts (suppressed: 2 from 2)
--12585--
--12585-- used_suppression:      2 glibc-2.5.x-on-SUSE-10.2-(PPC)-2a

The StartLog output should also show continuous operation with no crash/restart sequences.

2013-Aug-09 12:37:40 by johnkn:
REVIEW: Use after free is avoided in this patch by having r_cur be a Claim object and not a pointer into the r_claims list, (which now isn't used at all unless consumption policy is enabled). Other than the gratuitious changes to slot_builder.cpp, the new code in the startd is (almost) entirely disabled when consumption policy is not configured.

There is some new code for param'ing SLOT_WEIGHTS which will abort the STARTD if the slot weight expression does not parse. It's not clear to me whether this code is a useful but unrelated change, if it's purely for consumption policy use then it should be disabled unless consumption policy is enabled.
